results.title: [Brookes Family Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
This film shows a family ski trip to Falls Creek. We see the interior and exterior of the Winterhaven Ski Lodge and children being towed along by a ski tow. There are closeups and wide shots of skiers as they navigate their way around what appears to be a beginner’s ski run.

The film shows a children’s group ski lesson, a poma and T-bar lift, children skiing towards the camera and people being towed up the slope by the Village T-Bar ski tow. The children learn to ‘hop’ and the signal for ‘follow me’.

We see an adult couple preparing to ski with what appears to be a 1950s/1960s Volkswagen Beetle and pick-up truck parked in the background.

There are some lovely snow-covered landscapes of Falls Creek with people skiing in the sunshine against the backdrop of a bright blue sky.

A Snow Cat (vehicle) drives through the snow, passing ski lodges on the way.

A teenage boy runs beside a creek at the foot of a snow-covered embankment. We see a fishing expedition to the same creek, where fishing rods are prepared with bait and tackle, and two men and a boy cast their rods into the creek.

On the deck of Winterhaven Lodge, a group of people wearing shorts, swimwear and sunglasses lie on sun lounges enjoying the winter sun with the snow-covered embankment behind them. A woman wearing a bikini lies on a sun lounge beside her male companion who smokes and reads a book. Both are sporting 1960s sunglasses in the winter sun. We see a view from the deck of the ski lodge, showing snow-covered hills and surrounding ski lodges below.

The final section of the film follows a lone skier as he traverses his way down an empty slope.

This film shows good examples of fashion, ski wear, swimwear and sunglasses worn in the 60s. Ski Lodge architecture, vehicles and Falls Creek landscapes in this film are also a great reflection of the era.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Film title: “Falls Creek 1962”
00:03:20:00 Father and son in tandem being pulled together on a tow rope
00:09:37:00 Ski School lesson with children
00:09:54:00 Man and woman preparing to ski with Volkswagen Beetle and c1950s pick-up truck parked in the background. Good fashion and vehicle example here
00:11:06:00 Wide shot of four skiers skiing down a slope
00:19:28:00 High shot taken from ski lodge of boy with skis with a snow-covered sunbed in the background
00:19:35:00 Vintage Snow Cat (vehicle) travels through the snow with dogs following, passing ski lodges along the way
00:22:06:00 Skiers and the landscape of Falls Creek
00:22:23:00 Snow and creek vista
00:22:45:00 Boy playing beside creek in the snow
00:23:54:00 Creek snow fishing expedition
00:25:48:00 People lounging in sun beds at the ski lodge, dressed in shorts, swimwear and sunglasses
00:26:02:00 View from the deck of the ski lodge showing snow-covered hills and lodges below
00:26:10:00 Woman lying on sun lounge wearing a bikini and eating an orange
00:26:21:00 Man lying on sun lounge smoking and reading a book
00:26:51:00 View of snow-covered hills and lodges
00:27:28:00 A lone skier skis down an empty slope

results.title: [Brookes Family Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
This film shows a family visit to the beach and backyard play in Point Lonsdale c1950s -1960s. We see the children (James, Andrew and Margaret) with their mother and father playing on the seashore, building sandcastles together and drawing pictures in the sand. Joined by their pet dog, the children fill their buckets with sand and play with seaweed washed up onto the beach. There are good closeups of the children, reflecting examples of children’s fashion and hairstyles of the era.

We see the children venture out to the edge of the water and then play along the top of the seawall. There is great delight while eating ice cream from cones, and tears shed when an adult takes an uninvited taste.

The second, third and fourth sections of the film show the children on a summer’s day in a backyard. Tricycles, a blow-up wading pool with the backyard hose leading into it, swings and a sand pit create a great snapshot of children’s recreation, toys, and equipment particular to the era. We also see a young boy kicking what appears to be an American shaped football and two boys playing with toy cars and a toy police car.

The fifth section of the film shows a young baby being held by her mother. We then see the baby lying in her pram and being closely inspected and entertained by her older sibling.

We then go back to the beach with three very young children playing on the water’s edge with their mother beside them. Adults sit on the sand socialising, and there are scenes on the veranda of a holiday house. We see great examples of beach fashion, women’s hats, and children’s swimsuits.

This film shows examples of Victoria in the summertime, beach, women’s fashion and children’s fashion, children’s swim wear, vintage toys and a perambulator, children’s leisure and recreation activities that reflect the time.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:18:00 Mother and three boys playing in the sand
00:02:25:00 Children filling buckets with sand
00:02:36:00 Two children filling buckets with sand
00:03:09:00 Young boy crawling along the sea wall
00:03:34:00 Eating ice creams from cones, offering to share with passers by
00:03:50:00 Close up of eating ice cream
00:06:25:00 Three children on their tricycles with backyard swing
00:06:56:00 Two boys swing on their backyard bench swing
00:07:03 :00 Three children on swing
00:07:24:00 Children playing in sandpit
00:08:36:00 Nice wide shot of children playing on swing and in the sandpit
00:09:52:00 Three children playing in blow up wading pool
00:10:17:00 Three children crowded on a backyard swing together
00:10:32:00 Children trying to move wading pool full of water across the grass
00:12:44:00 Boys play with toy police car in sand pit
00:14:08:00 Children play with what appears to be an American shaped football
00:15:32:00 Boy riding on vintage tricycle in front of house
00:17:13:00 Baby in vintage pram with sibling peering in and attempting to play
00:17:53:00 Mother and three very young children sit at the water’s edge
00:18:15:00 Very young child at water’s edge – good example of children’s swim wear
00:20:28:00 Family on veranda of holiday house with seascape in background
00:21:48:00 Three women sitting on the beach wearing great hats
00:22:51:00 Great family beach scene as above

results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 1 - Red
results.brief_description:
Cyberthon V: Spectrum 1 Red was broadcast as the first of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

A selection of artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Space Between the Gaps (Paul Gafney), abcTVxyz (Dale Nason), The Visitor (Andrew Till) and Third Eye (Ollie Olsen).

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 1 Red is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: The Voice of Agriculture
results.creator_credit: Tony Doogood and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: Produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, this short film is an advertisement for the radio broadcast “The Voice of Agriculture”. Typical of the (now outdated) representation of gender roles of the time, the film opens with a domestic scene in which the mother of the family is making dinner while her husband discusses farm work. The farmer, who is having trouble with his sheep, calls on professional help from a veterinarian at the Department of Agriculture, who informs him about the radio program “The Voice of Agriculture”, which is designed to help farmers like him. The film then shows the behind-the-scenes production of the broadcast, including voice actors, radio technicians and vintage wireless sets.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tony Doogood and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture

results.title: [Stelarc: Stretched Skin No.4 Munich 1977]
results.brief_description:
This video footage is of a suspension performance entitled “Event for Stretched Skin No. 4” that took place at the Art Academy in Munich, Germany on 8 August 1977.

As the name suggests, this was Stelarc’s fourth suspension performance, in which the artist’s body is suspended in space by a series of hooks inserted into the skin. The artist began performing these durational performances in Japan in 1976; this was his first international performance.

In the video, we see the hooks being pierced into the skin across the back and front of the body. The body is then suspended upside down from a sculptural structure made out of logs of wood. The body hangs with arms outstretched in front of the windows of the Art Academy, showing Munich in the background. The performance is observed by a team of assistants, photographers and a small audience.

This performance was originally filmed on 1/2 inch videotape.

results.title: Stelarc Moving Image Collection
results.brief_description:
The Stelarc Collection is the moving image archive of Australian performance artist Stelarc. The collection consists of documentation of events and performances throughout the career of the pioneering body artist from the 1970s to the 2000s. Renowned for pushing his body to its limits through durational performance, body modification and surgical enhancement, Stelarc has established a decades-long practice that explores the intersection between the human body and technology, proposing a post-human understanding of the world. This unique archive of video and photographic documentation spans the artist’s early hook suspensions and internal body probes to performances with a robotic third arm and experiments in virtual realities.

The collection is housed on a variety of formats used since the introduction of video in the 1970s, including reel-to-reel tape, VHS, U-Matic, SP Betacam and Mini DV. These variable formats are currently being digitised to ensure the preservation and legacy of the artist’s archive.

The Stelarc Collection has been generously donated to ACMI by the artist through the Cultural Gifts Program.

results.title: [Stelarc: Event for Modified Man 1976]
results.brief_description:
This video is documentation of a performance entitled “Modulate / Meditate: Event for Modified Man” held at Tamura Gallery in Tokyo, Japan, from 26 January to 1 February 1976.

In this durational performance, Stelarc has hooks inserted into his back and sews first his lips and then his eyelids closed with a needle and thread. In the gallery are TV monitors including one showing an X-ray of his own body. Standing in the centre of the gallery with the hooks attached to the wall behind him, the artist captures the sounds of his own body – heartbeat, breath and blood rushing – which are then amplified throughout the space. In the latter part of the video, the participation of the body comes to an end: the artist removes the stitches from his eyelids and mouth and the hooks are removed.

This performance was originally filmed on 1/2 inch videotape.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 33]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

This film shows a trip to Wilson’s Promontory, Victoria including the beach at Tidal River and a group of people hiking around the prom.

Originally made on Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:38:00 a banksia tree
00:01:02:00 group of people walking onto a beach with large boulders
00:01:37:00 taking photos on the shoreline
00:02:35:00 woman sketching
00:05:49:00 a little lizard
00:06:27:00 group of people hiking
00:07:43:00 man sitting on a rock looking over a view
00:08:05:00 group of people watching the view
00:09:56:00 the river going into the sea
00:12:23:00 the footbridge at Tidal River
00:14:12:00 a rosella on a branch and feeding from someone’s hand

results.title: [Tony Agapitos: Easter celebrations at Green Hill]
results.brief_description:
This film shows Greek Easter celebrations, including a community BBQ, cooking lamb on a spit, music and dancing.

This film is part of a collection of 16mm films made by Tony Agapitos. The collection offers a glimpse at Greek migrant life in Victoria from the 1950s to the 1970s.

results.title: [Tony Agapitos: Miss Greek Charity Quest]
results.brief_description:
This silent film shows people at the Athenaeum Club in Melbourne celebrating the New Year and finalists of the Miss Greek Charity Quest.

This film is part of a collection of 16mm films made by Tony Agapitos. The collection offers a glimpse at Greek migrant life in Victoria from the 1950s to the 1970s.
